The dragon egg has finally hatched, and the creature within is yours to raise. In Velox Resurrected, players explore the bond between dragons and the natural world, using their abilities to survive, travel, and dominate the skies. Dragons once ruled the world—now they serve you, and every choice in how you raise them is yours.

Velox Resurrected allows players to obtain and raise many dragon types, including Aether, Cherry, End, Fire, Forest, Ghost, Ice, Nether, Pumpkin, Red Panda (Velox only), Sculk, Soul Sand, and Water dragons. A dragon egg can be obtained by slaying the Ender Dragon, with a smaller chance of finding one while exploring dungeons.

Once an egg is acquired and placed safely, players can either hatch it immediately or place it in a special habitat to let it adapt to its surroundings, which changes the dragon’s breed. After the egg is properly placed, right-clicking begins the hatching process, which can take up to an hour. Players should remain nearby until the dragon hatches.

To tame a dragon, it must be fed its preferred food. By default, raw fish is used, but some dragons require specific items, such as cherry leaves for the Cherry Dragon or bamboo for the Red Panda Dragon. Each dragon has unique textures, stats, and abilities, ranging from healing their owner to scaring mobs or generating plants as they move.

Dragons can be ridden by equipping them with a saddle and right-clicking. Use the spacebar to ascend and the Z key to descend while flying. If a dragon is injured, its health can be restored by feeding it meat, or by using healing spells if the player has magical abilities.

Goblin Traders are passive creatures added by the Goblin Traders mod. They commonly spawn in caves or mining tunnels after a player spends a significant amount of time underground. Their presence can be detected by a distinctive sound described in-game as a "lazy grunt." There is no strict limit to how many Goblin Traders can appear in a single area; instead, the most important factor influencing their spawn is how long the player remains underground.

Goblin Traders are completely non-hostile and will not attack the player, even if provoked. Their primary value lies in their trading utility. They offer exchanges that help reduce repetitive mining and processing tasks, such as trading emeralds for cobblestone, flint for gravel, and ore ingots for their corresponding raw ores. These trades are especially useful because Goblin Traders always return more resources than they receive.

For example, when a player trades 2 raw iron, they receive 3 iron ingots in return. This mechanic effectively removes the need for smelting while also providing a resource bonus. In addition to material trades, Goblin Traders can help maintain anvils and preserve enchantments on tools, offering further quality-of-life improvements for players who spend a lot of time mining.

One important limitation to note is that Goblin Traders take a long time to reset their trades. Players should plan their interactions accordingly, as repeated or rapid trading with the same goblin is not immediately possible.

The Conjurer is the second boss encountered in Normal mode. This boss can be found inside a structure known as the Theater, which spawns in several forest biomes including Dark Forest, Blackwood Forest, Sakura Grove, Blooming Valley, and Lavender Forest. The Conjurer waits for the player on the stage of the Theater, while pillagers populate both the interior and the surrounding area, making the encounter more dangerous before the boss fight even begins.

The Conjurer uses two primary offensive attacks. The first attack involves shooting round projectiles that bounce off walls, making them difficult to avoid in enclosed spaces. The second attack consists of throwing magical cards directly at the player, dealing damage on impact.

In addition to these attacks, The Conjurer has several special abilities that increase the complexity of the fight. He can summon angry rabbits from his hat, which aggressively attack the player and create additional pressure during combat. When The Conjurer takes damage, he is able to turn invisible, temporarily hiding his position. He can also teleport both himself and the player around the Theater room, disorienting the player and making positioning more challenging.

Despite his invisibility ability, The Conjurer can still be tracked by observing particle effects that reveal his location. Players preparing for this encounter can obtain a map to the Theater by trading with a Cartographer villager, allowing them to locate the structure more easily before engaging the boss.

Incubation is a small mod developed by Team Abnormals that focuses on expanding egg-related mechanics in Minecraft. First released on February 7, 2020, the mod introduces a variety of features centered around eggs, farming, and light automation, including new consumables, nests, and storage blocks designed to improve how eggs are collected and used.

The mod adds new food items such as the Fried Egg and Scrambled Egg. A Fried Egg is created by cooking a regular egg and restores 2 hunger points. Scrambled Eggs are crafted using two eggs of any type, milk, and a bowl, restoring 3 hunger points, making them a slightly more efficient food option.

Incubation also introduces several new blocks and items. Twig Nests naturally generate in the world, while Hay Nests can be crafted using five wheat. These nests are designed to interact with chickens, which prefer to lay their eggs on nearby nests rather than randomly on the ground. Each nest can store up to six eggs and can be emptied automatically using a hopper, allowing for simple egg farming setups.

For storage purposes, the mod adds Chicken Egg Crates and Turtle Egg Crates. These blocks are crafted from nine chicken eggs or nine turtle eggs respectively and function as compact storage blocks for large quantities of eggs. Overall, Incubation enhances farming gameplay by adding immersive, practical systems for egg production, storage, and consumption.

The Treasure Reforging addon introduces a recycling system that allows players to repurpose excess dungeon loot into new and useful equipment components. Instead of discarding unwanted or duplicate gear, players can break down certain high-tier equipment into specialized materials and reuse them through reforging mechanics. This system relies on new smithing templates, which are combined with materials obtained by smelting specific types of dungeon equipment.

Different equipment sets yield different materials when recycled. Neptune equipment can be smelted down into Neptune Mesh, which serves as a core crafting component for reforged Neptune gear. Valkyrie equipment can be broken down into Valkyrum Ingots, while Phoenix equipment yields Pyral Ingots when processed. These materials form the backbone of the reforging system and allow players to convert old loot into meaningful upgrades or alternative equipment choices.

In addition to standard equipment recycling, the addon provides further utility through Sun Altar breakdowns. Sun Altars can be dismantled into Pyral Shards, which can then be recrafted into Pyral Ingots using Obsidian. Pyral Shards also have a secondary use, as they can be consumed to reignite Obsidian Armor, adding longevity and maintenance options for powerful gear.

For storage and crafting efficiency, Valkyrum Ingots and Pyral Ingots can be compacted into block forms. Overall, the Treasure Reforging addon enhances dungeon progression by rewarding exploration with flexible resource management, encouraging players to recycle loot and customize their equipment rather than relying solely on random drops.

The Protect Your Moa addon expands how Moas can be used during exploration by introducing new equipment and utility options. The addon focuses on improving Moa survivability and functionality, making them more reliable companions for long journeys and dangerous environments.

One of the core features is Moa Armor, which can be crafted and equipped to provide Moas with increased protection. Different armor types offer unique benefits depending on the Moa variant. For example, Gravitite Moa Armor grants additional jumping abilities, enhancing mobility and traversal in vertical or difficult terrain.

In addition to armor, players can equip Moas with chests. This allows Moas to function as mobile storage units, enabling players to carry extra items while exploring without relying solely on their own inventory. This feature is especially useful for extended expeditions where inventory management becomes critical.

Overall, the Protect Your Moa addon enhances exploration gameplay by turning Moas into more durable, versatile, and practical mounts through added defense, special abilities, and portable storage options.

Farmers Structures is an add-on for Farmer’s Delight that introduces a wide variety of naturally generated structures designed to showcase and teach the mechanics of the Farmer’s Delight mod. These structures are not only visually appealing but also practical, helping players learn cooking, food preparation, and survival systems in an immersive way.

The mod adds over 50 unique, randomly generated structures using a jigsaw-based generation system. Many of these structures function as small homes that are ideal for starter bases or temporary vacation spots. They typically include essentials such as a bed, crafting table, and food items that often require cooking, subtly encouraging players to interact with Farmer’s Delight mechanics.

All structures follow a simple, vanilla-friendly aesthetic that blends seamlessly into the Minecraft world. Large, intrusive buildings and unrealistic materials are intentionally avoided. Structures are carefully integrated into terrain, minimizing unnatural platforms or sharp edges within the limits of vanilla world generation. Resource placement is balanced to ensure that progression and gameplay difficulty remain intact.

Farmers Structures strictly respects vanilla progression rules. Nether blocks do not appear in the overworld, and no materials are used in ways that would break immersion or game balance. The builds are thoughtfully designed to demonstrate Farmer’s Delight recipes, tools, and cooking systems while remaining compatible with popular Farmer’s Delight addons.

Any structure added by the mod can be located using the command /locate structure farmers_structures:, allowing players to easily explore and study the builds if desired.

Immersive Lanterns is a small utility-focused mod that allows players to wear lanterns using the Accessories mod, providing hands-free lighting with immersive visuals and dynamic lighting support. The mod is designed to solve the common problem of choosing between holding a torch or a shield, especially during exploration or combat-heavy gameplay.

Players can equip a lantern by crafting one and then crouch-right-clicking while holding it. This action places the lantern into an Accessories slot, where it hangs visibly from the player’s belt. Once equipped, the lantern emits light around the player, allowing continuous illumination without occupying the main hand or offhand.

A key feature of Immersive Lanterns is its custom swinging physics. As the player moves, the lantern behaves like a pendulum, swinging naturally in third-person view. This adds a strong sense of realism and immersion compared to static light sources or simple inventory-based solutions.

The mod also supports dynamic lighting, ensuring that the lantern actively lights the surrounding area as the player moves. While other mods offer similar wearable lighting features, Immersive Lanterns stands out by providing full compatibility with Iris shaderpacks that include their own dynamic lighting systems. This allows lanterns to visually adapt to shader effects.

For example, equipping a Soul Lantern while using the Complementary shaderpack produces blue-colored lighting instead of standard light. This deep shader integration makes Immersive Lanterns a strong choice for players who prioritize immersion, visuals, and seamless exploration without sacrificing combat readiness.

Ferrous Wroughtnauts are hostile boss mobs encountered within structures known as Wrought Chambers. Each Wrought Chamber generates with exactly one Ferrous Wroughtnaut during world generation, and these structures notably contain no chests or loot containers. Wroughtnauts are heavily armored knights wielding massive axes and are among the most mechanically demanding boss encounters due to their near-total immunity to damage.

When idle, a Ferrous Wroughtnaut stands motionless with its arms resting on its axe. Once a player approaches or attacks it, the boss becomes active and begins combat. During fights, Wroughtnauts emit eerie, ghostly groans. Outside of combat, they rapidly regenerate health. They are immune to all sources of damage except during specific attack animations, namely the axe slam and vertical swing attacks, where a vulnerable wound on their back can be struck. Defeating one grants the "Just A Flesh Wound" advancement.

In combat, the Wroughtnaut slowly marches toward its target and periodically performs powerful attacks. Its Axe Swing attack deals massive damage and instantly breaks shields, gaining additional combo swings as its health drops below 50% and 25%. The Axe Slam is its strongest attack, embedding the axe into the ground and briefly exposing its weak point. The Stomp attack launches nearby blocks, damages and knocks back entities, and can be avoided by precise jumping.

Upon death, Ferrous Wroughtnauts drop guaranteed boss loot. They always drop the Wrought Helm and the Axe of a Thousand Metals, making them a high-risk but high-reward encounter for well-prepared players.

Umvuthi, the Sunbird is a large neutral boss mob found seated on a throne within the Umvuthana Grove. He is a powerful heliomancer and the creator of the Abavuthana. Umvuthi never leaves his throne and will attack nearby hostile mobs such as Zombies, Skeletons, Drowned, and Husks, as well as any players who are not wearing an Umvuthana Mask or who misbehave within the grove. While not in combat, he passively regenerates health. Defeating Umvuthi grants the player the Praise The Sun advancement, and all nearby Abavuthana die upon his defeat.

During combat, Umvuthi alternates between several solar-based attacks. Sunstrike calls down fiery strikes at a target’s location, dealing damage and igniting entities, with increasing frequency as his health decreases. Solar Flare damages and knocks back nearby targets when they approach too closely. Once below 60 health, Umvuthi gains access to Solar Beam, firing a sustained beam that repeatedly damages entities in its path. His most devastating ability is Supernova, which pulls entities inward before detonating in a large explosion that can set targets on fire.

Umvuthi can also summon Abavuthana if too few are nearby, and when his health drops to 75 or lower, he summons Umvuthana Cranes to heal him, granting an unbreakable shield until they are defeated. Outside of combat, Umvuthi offers trading to players wearing an Umvuthana Mask. In exchange for seven Blocks of Gold, he grants the Sun’s Blessing for 60 minutes, which can later be renewed for free as long as the player keeps the mask equipped.

When slain, Umvuthi always drops a Sol Visage and one to two Feathers. The Sol Visage can be worn and used to summon Umvuthana minions by right-clicking while holding another Umvuthana Mask.

Tongbi, the Sculptor is a simian-themed neutral boss mob found within Monastery structures. One Tongbi spawns at the center of each Monastery during world generation, making him a guaranteed encounter for players who explore these locations. Unlike many boss mobs, Tongbi does not immediately engage in combat and instead offers an alternative, skill-based interaction.

Tongbi is neutral by default and will not attack the player unless provoked. His primary purpose is to test the player’s agility and movement skills rather than raw combat strength. Through trading, Tongbi can offer a special item known as the Bluff Rod, which initiates a parkour-style challenge. This test emphasizes precision jumping, timing, and traversal, rewarding players who successfully complete it.

Players who choose to attack and defeat Tongbi instead of completing his challenge will still receive valuable rewards, though they are less predictable. Upon death, Tongbi drops a random piece of the Geomancy armor set, making him a potential source of powerful earth-themed equipment for players focused on combat.

However, players who complete Tongbi’s parkour challenge are guaranteed a specific and highly desirable reward. Successfully passing the test ensures that Tongbi drops the Earthrend Gauntlet, a powerful Geomancy item that cannot be guaranteed through combat alone. This design encourages players to engage with Tongbi’s intended mechanics rather than relying solely on brute force.

Overall, Tongbi, the Sculptor stands out as a boss encounter that rewards skillful movement and problem-solving, offering players a unique alternative to traditional combat-focused boss fights.

Nagas are large, flying hostile mobs that inhabit coastal cliffs, most commonly spawning in Stony Shores biomes. They are venomous, winged serpents capable of overwhelming players with both ranged and melee attacks. Due to terrain changes introduced in Minecraft 1.18, Stony Shores biomes appear more frequently, resulting in unusually large swarms of Nagas spawning. This behavior is a known issue, and a fix is reportedly in development.

Nagas spawn in packs and immediately become aggressive when a player approaches. Their primary ranged attack involves spitting acid balls that deal heavy damage, typically around five to six hearts, while also inflicting poison. In close combat, Nagas can swoop down toward players and perform a spinning attack that deals approximately four to five hearts of damage.

In addition to their strong attacks, Nagas are highly mobile and capable of dodging incoming arrows, making ranged combat more challenging. However, if a Naga is successfully struck by an arrow, it will briefly lose control, flailing and crashing to the ground. This moment of vulnerability allows players to close the distance and deal extra damage before the Naga recovers.

Upon death, Nagas drop Naga Fangs. The quantity dropped increases with the Looting enchantment, making them a reliable source of this item for players who repeatedly hunt them. Overall, Nagas are dangerous aerial predators that require careful positioning and timing to defeat effectively.

Bluffs are hostile mobs encountered within Monastery structures. They are aggressive stone-based enemies that pose a threat through terrain-manipulating attacks rather than direct melee combat. Bluffs are notable for being the only source of Bluff Rods, which they drop upon death, making them a key target for players seeking this unique item.

Bluffs spawn naturally throughout monasteries, particularly in halls and corridors, and may also appear from mob spawners located within these structures. This makes monasteries a consistent but dangerous location for farming Bluff Rods, as multiple Bluffs can appear in confined spaces.

In terms of behavior, Bluffs are immediately hostile toward players and will attack on sight. They are also aggressive toward Iron Golems, Snow Golems, and Wandering Traders. If attacked by other mobs, Bluffs will retaliate against most attackers, with the exception of creepers and ghasts, which they ignore.

Their primary method of attack involves raising an earth block directly at the player’s location. This attack can disrupt movement, deal damage, and create sudden obstacles, making positioning and awareness especially important during combat. Because of their environmental manipulation and confined spawning areas, Bluffs can be deceptively dangerous when encountered in groups.

Overall, Bluffs serve as both a combat challenge and a progression gate within monasteries, encouraging players to engage carefully in order to obtain Bluff Rods while navigating tight interiors and constant ambush potential.

Foliaaths are common hostile mobs found in jungle biomes. They are carnivorous plant creatures that prey on anything that comes too close, blending naturally into dense jungle foliage to ambush unsuspecting targets.

Foliaaths spawn naturally in jungle biomes and camouflage themselves as ordinary ferns. While inactive, only their fern-like base is visible, and they remain completely invulnerable, making them difficult to distinguish from normal vegetation. This camouflage allows them to surprise players and mobs that wander too close.

When a valid target approaches, a Foliaath reveals its head and becomes aggressive. It attacks by biting nearby creatures and players, dealing damage at close range. Once all nearby targets are eliminated or move out of range, the Foliaath returns to its inactive state, once again appearing as a harmless fern and regaining invulnerability.

Foliaaths gain additional strength from successful kills. Each time a Foliaath kills any entity, it is granted Regeneration II for 15 seconds, allowing it to quickly recover health and making prolonged encounters more dangerous if other mobs are nearby.

When defeated by the player, Foliaaths have a chance to drop a Foliaath Seed. These drops are occasional rather than guaranteed, encouraging repeated encounters for players seeking this item. Overall, Foliaaths are deceptive ambush predators that reward cautious exploration and careful observation in jungle environments.

Frostmaw is a large, rare hostile boss mob and the largest creature in its mod, found in cold and icy biomes such as Snowy Plains, Ice Spikes, and other snowy regions. Frostmaws spawn above grass or ice and begin encounters in a dormant state, sleeping while guarding an Ice Crystal held in their hand. Players can steal this Ice Crystal before combat to significantly reduce the boss’s ranged capabilities.

When approached or attacked, a sleeping Frostmaw awakens, swallows its Ice Crystal if still holding it, roars to announce the fight, and begins attacking. Frostmaws are highly resilient bosses, immune to arrows and thrown tridents, and capable of jumping to escape lava. If a Frostmaw remains without a target for one minute, it returns to sleep and restores the Ice Crystal to its hand. Frostmaws are aggressive toward Iron Golems and Snow Golems on sight.

In combat, Frostmaw alternates between several powerful attacks. Swipe attacks deal heavy frontal damage and may chain into double swipes with a chance to disable shields. Slam attacks are only used below 60% health and deal massive damage while instantly breaking shields, making them the most dangerous move. Frostmaw can also use Ice Breath to slow and freeze players at close range, and Ice Balls to freeze distant targets, though both ice-based attacks are disabled if the Ice Crystal is stolen. Frostmaw may also roar to knock nearby entities away without dealing damage.

Upon defeat, Frostmaw always drops an Ice Crystal and the Petiole music disc, making it a rewarding but challenging encounter for well-prepared players in cold biomes.

Umvuthana, with the plural form Abavuthana, are bird-like neutral mobs found primarily in Savanna biomes and within Umvuthana Groves. They are naturally hostile toward players unless the player is wearing an Umvuthana mask. While neutral, they can be traded with and act as part of a structured hunting pack system tied to Umvuthi, the Sunbird.

Abavuthana spawn in groups of four as hunting packs in Savanna biomes and also generate naturally inside Umvuthana Groves. They may additionally appear through Umvuthi’s summoning abilities or be summoned by players wearing the Sol Visage. In combat, Abavuthana attack by slashing their claws and prefer to circle their targets at a distance before closing in. They are aggressive toward players, common passive animals, zombies, and skeletons. Each pack follows an Umvuthana Raptor, and once the Raptor is defeated, the pack disperses.

Abavuthana are immune to magma block and campfire damage, and when moving they leave visible footprints on the ground. Player-summoned Abavuthana will follow their owner and attack any mob the owner targets, and they can be dismissed by right-clicking to recover their mask.

Abavuthana remain neutral toward players wearing Umvuthana masks but become aggressive if the player attacks an Umvuthana or Umvuthi, or opens chests within the grove. Each mask grants a passive status effect, such as Jump Boost, Swiftness, Resistance, or Haste, depending on the mask type worn.

Players wearing masks may trade with Abavuthana for food, gold nuggets, feathers, campfires, and other basic resources. When killed, Abavuthana drop one to two feathers and occasionally their mask, which can be worn for bonuses or used with the Sol Visage to summon additional Umvuthana.

The Axe of a Thousand Metals is a powerful weapon associated with the Ferrous Wroughtnaut. Ferrous Wroughtnauts always drop an Axe of a Thousand Metals upon death, making it a guaranteed boss loot item. Although the boss wields the axe during combat, the weapon is not actually stored in its inventory and is instead built directly into the Wroughtnaut’s model.

When used by the Ferrous Wroughtnaut, the Axe of a Thousand Metals has two devastating attacks. One attack is a wide side swing that deals 30 damage, while the second slams the axe into the ground, dealing 45 damage and temporarily immobilizing the Wroughtnaut. This slam attack is significantly stronger than the player version and represents the peak power of the weapon when wielded by the boss.

In the hands of a player, the Axe of a Thousand Metals is still a strong melee weapon but noticeably weaker than when used by the Wroughtnaut. A standard left-click attack deals 9 melee damage with a slow attack speed of 0.9. By right-clicking, players can perform a swing attack similar to the boss’s side swing, though it only deals 7 damage. This attack is useful for hitting multiple enemies in front of the player.

The axe also features a special slam ability. By crouching and right-clicking on the ground, the player can slam the axe to create a shockwave extending up to 10 blocks. The direct hit deals 9 melee damage, while the shockwave damage scales based on distance from the impact point.

According to trivia, much of the axe’s power is lost when the Ferrous Wroughtnaut is defeated. This explains why the weapon is significantly stronger in the boss’s hands and reinforces its identity as a legendary tool whose full strength dies with its wielder.

Sun’s Blessing is a powerful temporary status effect obtained by trading with Umvuthi, the Sunbird. Players can acquire this blessing by exchanging seven Blocks of Gold with Umvuthi while wearing the appropriate Umvuthana mask. Once obtained, Sun’s Blessing grants the player access to several solar-based abilities inspired by Umvuthi’s own attacks.

With Sun’s Blessing active, players can right-click the ground to call down a Sun Strike from the sky, damaging enemies at the targeted location. By shift-right-clicking, players can unleash a Sun Beam directly from themselves, firing a powerful solar attack forward. Pressing shift and left-click allows the use of Solar Flare, creating an area-of-effect burst that deals damage and applies strong knockback to nearby entities. The most powerful ability, Supernova, is activated by pressing shift, left-click, and right-click simultaneously. This attack pulls nearby entities toward the player before triggering a fiery explosion that deals heavy damage.

The Sun’s Blessing effect lasts for one hour, but the countdown does not begin until the player uses one of its abilities. Some abilities are free to use, while others consume the remaining duration. Sun Strike and Solar Flare do not reduce the effect duration at all. Using Sun Beam reduces the remaining time by five minutes, while activating Supernova immediately removes the Sun’s Blessing effect entirely.

After the Sun’s Blessing effect expires, players can return to Umvuthi to replenish the blessing for free, allowing repeated use without additional gold costs as long as Umvuthi remains available.

Foliaath Seed is a plantable item used to spawn a Baby Foliaath. It is directly tied to Foliaath mobs and serves as the primary method for players to intentionally create new Foliaaths rather than encountering them naturally in the world.

Foliaath Seeds are obtained as mob drops. When a Foliaath is killed, it can drop between zero and two Foliaath Seeds by default. Weapons enchanted with Looting increase the potential yield, granting one additional possible seed per Looting level. With Looting III, players can obtain up to five Foliaath Seeds from a single Foliaath, making enchantments useful for farming this item.

In terms of usage, Foliaath Seeds can be planted on several ground types, including grass blocks, podzol, and dirt paths. When a seed is planted on a valid block, it immediately spawns a Baby Foliaath at that location instead of growing through multiple stages like conventional crops.

The spawned Baby Foliaath represents an early stage of the Foliaath mob and will eventually function as a full Foliaath. This allows players to deliberately place Foliaaths for controlled encounters, farms, or decorative purposes. Because Foliaaths are hostile ambush mobs, planting these seeds should be done carefully, especially in survival environments.

Overall, Foliaath Seeds provide a direct way to reproduce Foliaaths and interact with their lifecycle, giving players more control over how and where these dangerous plant creatures appear.

Naga Fangs are items dropped by Nagas and serve as key progression materials tied to defeating these dangerous flying mobs. They represent the primary reward for hunting Nagas and are used in both crafting and brewing, making them valuable for combat-oriented and survival-focused gameplay.

Naga Fangs are obtained exclusively through mob loot. When a Naga is killed, it drops between zero and one Naga Fang by default. Using a weapon enchanted with Looting increases the potential drop amount, adding one additional possible fang per Looting level. With Looting III, players can receive up to four Naga Fangs from a single Naga, significantly improving farming efficiency for this resource.

In terms of usage, Naga Fangs function as crafting ingredients and brewing components. They are required to craft Naga Fang Daggers, weapons typically associated with poison-based combat and fast melee attacks. This makes them especially useful for players who prefer agile or status-effect-focused fighting styles.

Naga Fangs are also used in brewing to create Potions of Poison Resistance. These potions provide protection against poison effects, which are commonly inflicted by Nagas themselves and other venomous enemies. This creates a natural progression loop where defeating Nagas enables players to better defend against poison-based threats in future encounters.

Overall, Naga Fangs are a versatile drop that rewards players for overcoming challenging aerial enemies and supports both offensive weapon crafting and defensive potion brewing.

The Ice Crystal is a rare ranged weapon associated with the Frostmaw boss and is designed for crowd control through freezing effects. It allows players to generate icy whirlwinds that damage and immobilize enemies from a distance, making it especially useful in controlling aggressive mobs or creating openings in combat.

The Ice Crystal can be obtained in two different ways, both tied to encounters with Frostmaw. If a player approaches a sleeping Frostmaw quickly enough, the Ice Crystal can be stolen directly from its hand before it closes, weakening the boss before the fight begins. Alternatively, if the Frostmaw has already swallowed the crystal during combat, the Ice Crystal can be acquired by killing the Frostmaw, guaranteeing it as a drop.

When used, the Ice Crystal functions as a channeled weapon. By holding right-click while the Ice Crystal is in hand, the player summons an icy whirlwind in front of them. This whirlwind continuously deals 1 point of damage to enemies caught within it. After approximately three seconds of sustained contact, affected entities become frozen, rendering them unable to move for a short duration.

This freezing effect makes the Ice Crystal particularly effective for slowing down powerful enemies, managing groups, or setting up follow-up attacks with other weapons. Although its direct damage output is low, its ability to immobilize targets gives it strong utility value in both exploration and boss encounters.

Overall, the Ice Crystal is a unique control-focused weapon that rewards careful positioning and timing, offering strategic advantages rather than raw damage.

Earth Talisman is an item that can only be obtained in the Creative game mode. It grants the Geomancy effect while in the player's inventory.

The Earth Talisman is obtainable only in the Creative mode inventory or using commands.

While having the Earth Talisman inside the player's inventory, they will receive the Geomancy effect. This effect lets the player right-click the ground to summon Boulders of various sizes, depending on how long the right mouse button is hold. It also allows the player to tunnel, by double-tapping and holding sneak while on air.

The Deeper and Darker mod transforms Minecraft’s Deep Dark into a gateway to a completely new dimension filled with terrifying creatures, powerful equipment upgrades, and mysterious structures. This comprehensive expansion builds upon the Warden mechanics introduced in the 1.19 update, creating a natural progression for players. They will go from confronting the Warden in Ancient Cities to exploring the haunting realm known as the Otherside.

Players can look forward to discovering advanced armor sets that are even stronger than Netherite. They will have the opportunity to craft unique items such as the Soul Elytra and the Sonorous Staff, while also facing formidable boss creatures.

The journey will take place across three distinct biomes, each filled with exclusive resources and challenges. This guide will help players navigate every aspect of the mod, starting with the initial preparations needed to survive in the Otherside, and progressing to mastering the complex crafting systems required to create the most powerful equipment in Minecraft.

Success in the Otherside dimension requires extensive preparation, as this realm presents challenges that exceed even the Nether’s dangers. Players must gather specific equipment and resources before attempting to activate the portal, as the dimension’s unique properties make survival extremely difficult without proper gear.

The foundation of Otherside exploration begins with defeating the Warden, which drops two essential items: the Warden Carapace and the Heart of the Deep. The Warden retains its formidable 500 health points and devastating 30 attack damage, making this encounter one of the most challenging fights in vanilla Minecraft.

Players should approach this battle equipped with full Netherite armor, powerful weapons, and ample healing supplies. The Heart of the Deep functions as the activation key for the Otherside portal and cannot be obtained through any other means. This rare drop is consumed upon portal activation, so players planning multiple journeys must defeat additional Wardens or secure a reliable return method.

The Warden Carapace is used as a critical crafting ingredient for the Reinforced Echo Shard, which enables the upgrade of Netherite equipment into powerful Warden-tier gear, forming the backbone of late-game progression in the mod.

The Reinforced Echo Shard represents the bridge between vanilla Netherite equipment and the mod’s enhanced Warden gear. Crafting this item requires one Warden Carapace, four Echo Shards, and four Phantom Membranes. Echo Shards are found in Ancient City chests, while Phantom Membranes drop from Phantoms that spawn when players have not slept for several nights.

The materials must be arranged in a crafting table with Phantom Membrane, Warden Carapace, and Phantom Membrane across the top row; Warden Carapace, Echo Shard, and Warden Carapace in the middle row; and Phantom Membrane, Warden Carapace, and Phantom Membrane across the bottom row. This recipe produces one Reinforced Echo Shard, which can be used to upgrade any piece of Netherite equipment via a Smithing Table.

Upgrading Netherite gear further requires the Warden Upgrade Smithing Template. This template can be found in Ancient City chests with an approximate 60% chance. Like other Smithing Templates, it can be duplicated using seven Diamonds, one existing Warden Upgrade Smithing Template, and one Sculk block. Once players have both a Reinforced Echo Shard and a Warden Upgrade Smithing Template, they can upgrade Netherite equipment into Warden-tier gear that provides superior stats and special properties essential for surviving in the Otherside.

The Otherside dimension is extremely dark, limiting visibility to only a few blocks ahead. To survive effectively, players are strongly encouraged to obtain the Warden Helmet, which provides essential advantages for navigating this environment. Crafting the Warden Helmet requires defeating the Warden, which drops two new items: the Warden Carapace and the Heart of the Deep.

A single Warden Carapace can be combined with four Phantom Membranes and four Echo Shards to create a Reinforced Echo Shard. Phantom Membranes are dropped by Phantoms that spawn when players do not sleep for several nights, while Echo Shards can be found in chests located within Ancient Cities. The Reinforced Echo Shard is a key upgrade material for converting Netherite equipment into Warden-tier gear.

For players not yet ready to fight the Warden, an alternative method exists. New Ancient Vases found in Ancient Cities have a small chance to drop the Warden Carapace along with other resources. However, breaking these vases is risky, as each one has a chance to spawn the Stalker, a powerful boss enemy, and excessive noise may still summon the Warden.

Once a Reinforced Echo Shard is obtained, it can be applied to a Netherite Helmet using a Smithing Table to create the Warden Helmet. Other Netherite armor pieces such as Boots, Leggings, and Chestplate can also be upgraded, granting additional benefits including a movement speed boost. With the Warden Helmet equipped and sufficient supplies like food, armor, and building blocks, players are prepared to enter the Otherside.

To enter the Otherside, players must travel to an Ancient City and locate the Portal Frame. Before activation, all Sculk must be cleared from the frame, as its presence prevents the portal from functioning. Activation requires the Heart of the Deep, an item obtained exclusively by defeating the Warden. By right-clicking the cleared Portal Frame with the Heart of the Deep, the portal becomes active and allows travel to the Otherside.

The portal functions similarly to a Nether Portal, allowing players to return to the Overworld freely as long as the portal remains accessible. However, players are strongly advised to record the portal’s coordinates, as losing access to it leaves death as the only method of return.

Within the Otherside, players can explore several distinct biomes, including the Echoing Forest, Otherside Deeplands, and Overcast Columns. The Echoing Forest features Echo Trees illuminated by Sculk Gleam, which can be harvested for planks. Despite the new environment, the Warden is still capable of spawning here, requiring constant caution.

The Otherside Deeplands resemble Nether Wastes terrain and contain minimal natural lighting. Bone-based structures can generate throughout this biome, and large deposits of Sculk Gleam are found on ceilings, alongside frequent Phantom spawns. Sculk Stone generates throughout these regions and can be mined and crafted into various building blocks such as brick, tiled, and chiseled variants.

The Overcast Columns biome is composed primarily of Gloom Sculk, Gloom Slate, and Crystallized Amber. Geysers scattered across the floor can launch players into the air. Although cave systems do not generate in the Otherside, Overworld ores can still be found embedded within Sculk Stone. Gloom Slate can also be collected and crafted into additional decorative building blocks.

The Ancient Temple is a structure found within the Otherside Deeplands. Inside, players can discover multiple Chests and Vases containing valuable loot such as food, Echo Shards, Enchanted items, and Music Discs. By breaking the blocks located at the center of the structure, players can descend deeper into the temple, reaching a flooded chamber that contains additional Chests and Vases with further rewards.

Chests within the deeper sections of the Ancient Temple can contain the Sculk Transmitter. This unique item allows players to bind it to a Chest or Barrel, enabling remote access from a distance. Ancient Temples are also a reliable source of Sculk Stone Diamond Ore, which can be mined to obtain Diamonds.

Several hostile mobs inhabit the Otherside. In the Echoing Forest, players may encounter the Shattered, a wandering enemy that has a chance to drop Soul Dust when defeated. In the Deeplands, Sculk Centipedes can be found and slain for Sculk Bones. These creatures can be tamed using Enchanted Netherite Chestplates to occasionally provide Enchanted Books, though their behavior may currently be unstable and risky.

Infested Sculk blocks can trigger Shriek Worms when stepped on, causing them to emerge and attack the player. These enemies do not drop loot. Additionally, breaking Vases anywhere in the Otherside has a chance to spawn the Stalker, a dangerous boss mob. Defeating the Stalker is the primary method for obtaining the Soul Crystal, making these encounters both risky and rewarding.

An obtainable reward for exploration in the Otherside is the Soul Elytra, which acts as an upgrade to the standard Elytra. To craft it, players require one Elytra, four Sculk Bones, three Soul Dust, and one Soul Crystal. Aside from the Elytra itself, all required materials can be obtained from creatures found within the Otherside.

When equipped, the Soul Elytra has a random chance to provide a movement boost. This effect triggers so frequently that players rarely need to carry Firework Rockets for sustained flight. Sculk Bones are obtained from Sculk Centipedes, Soul Dust drops from the Shattered, and Soul Crystals are acquired by defeating the Stalker.

Before entering the Otherside, obtaining a Warden Helmet is strongly recommended, while other upgraded equipment is optional. Players may still choose to upgrade all Netherite armor and tools to Warden-themed variants. Additionally, the Sculk Smite enchantment can be applied to deal increased damage against Sculk-based creatures, further improving survivability and combat effectiveness in the Otherside.

Ixeris is a client-side performance optimization mod that improves Minecraft framerate smoothness by offloading event polling to a separate thread, freeing up more CPU time for rendering. Players may notice FPS drops when moving the mouse or turning the camera, partly due to legitimate tasks such as chunk visibility calculations. However, a significant portion of this slowdown comes from inefficiencies in native event polling code and JNI upcall overhead, where CPU time that could otherwise be used for rendering is instead consumed by calls to glfwPollEvents().

This issue is especially noticeable on Windows systems, and becomes more severe when using mice with high polling rates. In these situations, event polling can frequently block the render thread, resulting in stutters and inconsistent frame pacing during camera movement.

Ixeris resolves this problem by ensuring that glfwPollEvents() is handled in a way that no longer blocks the render thread. While GLFW retrieves events from the operating system, the render thread is able to continue its work uninterrupted. As a result, players experience significantly smoother camera movement and reduced stuttering when turning or looking around.

While Ixeris does not generally increase FPS when the player is standing still, it greatly improves frame consistency and perceived smoothness during active gameplay, particularly during mouse movement and camera rotation.

Easy Disenchanting is a vanilla-friendly mod that allows players to extract enchantments from gear using only an anvil, without adding any new blocks or items to the game. The mod is designed to integrate seamlessly with existing Minecraft mechanics, making it intuitive and familiar for players who prefer a minimal and balanced gameplay experience.

This mod is a rewrite of Enchantment Transfer, updated for newer Minecraft versions and improved with important bug fixes and enhancements. One of its key improvements is the ability to transfer enchantments not only onto empty books, but also onto already enchanted books. When combining enchantments, the mod follows the same rules as vanilla enchanted book merging, ensuring consistency with standard gameplay.

Using Easy Disenchanting is straightforward. Players simply place an enchanted item, such as a sword, together with a book into an anvil to extract the enchantments. If the goal is to merge enchantments onto an already enchanted book, the enchanted book must be placed in the first anvil slot. The resulting book will contain the combined enchantments, while the original item is returned to the player.

By default, the experience level cost matches vanilla enchantment combination costs, preserving balance. Both the cost and whether the original item is returned can be adjusted through the configuration file, allowing pack creators and players to fine-tune the mod to their preferred level of difficulty.

Early Bedtime is a lightweight, vanilla-friendly mod designed for modpack developers and server owners who want more control over when players are allowed to sleep. Instead of being locked to Minecraft’s default sleep timing, this mod makes it possible to configure how early sleeping becomes available during the day–night cycle, improving flexibility without introducing new mechanics or items.

By default, Early Bedtime allows players to sleep 1000 ticks earlier than vanilla Minecraft, which is roughly 50 seconds sooner. This value is fully configurable through the mod’s settings, allowing servers and modpacks to fine-tune the sleeping window to better match their desired gameplay balance or visual experience.

The primary motivation behind Early Bedtime is compatibility with shader packs. Many popular shaders feature highly exaggerated and dramatic sunsets that cause the world to appear very dark well before vanilla Minecraft normally allows sleeping. While this visual effect looks impressive, it can feel unintuitive when players are unable to sleep despite near-dark conditions.

For example, with shaders such as Hysteria, lighting conditions darken rapidly, but vanilla Minecraft still requires the sun to drop below the horizon before sleep is permitted. Early Bedtime resolves this mismatch by aligning sleep mechanics more closely with visual darkness, resulting in a smoother and more immersive experience for shader users.

This update introduces a speed of sound simulation, adding distance-based audio delays that make sound behavior more realistic and immersive. Sounds are delayed depending on how far their source is from the player. Thunder and explosion sounds are enabled by default with a speed of 100 blocks per second, while all other sounds are disabled by default and can be configured individually.

A new Doppler effect option has been added, enabled at 100% intensity by default. This feature dynamically adjusts sound pitch based on how quickly the distance between the player and the sound source changes, creating a more realistic sense of motion. Due to sound engine limitations, the Doppler effect does not function on mono sounds.

The update also includes a fix for the vanilla Minecraft bug MC-98200, where sound category volume sliders did not properly affect certain sounds at higher percentages. For example, music discs previously reached full volume at only 25% category volume; this behavior has now been corrected.

Additional changes include an updated settings menu and renamed or reformatted configuration keys. Older configuration formats are automatically converted to the new format to ensure a smooth transition. Several fixes were implemented, including compatibility with Sound Physics Remastered, improved custom music frequency distribution to ensure uniform playback chances, and enhanced mono audio support so sounds can now be positioned relative to the camera.

The Twilight Forest can only be accessed by creating a special portal in the Overworld. To construct the portal, players must dig a 2x2 hole, fill it with water, and surround the pool with natural decorative items such as flowers, plants, or mushrooms from vanilla Minecraft or compatible mods. Once the setup is complete, throwing a Diamond into the water will cause lightning to strike, transforming the pool into an active portal that leads to the Twilight Forest. Upon entering the dimension, a return portal back to the Overworld is automatically created.

When entering the Twilight Forest for the first time, it is strongly recommended to wait patiently while the dimension generates. The Twilight Forest is a large and complex dimension containing many different dungeons and structures, which can cause generation to take a noticeable amount of time. Players are also advised to mark the portal’s location on their minimap before exploring, as the vast size of the dimension makes it easy to become lost, even with an overhead map.

If a player loses their original portal and cannot find their way back, another Twilight Forest portal can be created by repeating the same process used in the Overworld. This ensures that players are never permanently stranded and can always return by recreating the portal conditions.

The Twilight Forest features a wide variety of unique saplings that grow into specialized trees, each offering distinct visual styles and gameplay functionality. The Sickly Twilight Oak Sapling grows into a smaller and spindly version of the classic Twilight Oak, providing a more compact tree form. The Canopy Tree Sapling produces an enormous tree with a wide, flat leaf canopy that casts a permanent shadow beneath it, significantly darkening the area below.

The Twilight Mangrove Sapling grows into a water-dependent tree with twisted root systems, commonly found in swamp-like environments. The Darkwood Sapling creates a tree with extremely dense leaves that block light, fitting the eerie atmosphere of the Dark Forest biome. For players seeking massive structures, the Robust Twilight Oak Sapling grows into a colossal oak tree capable of reaching the world height limit.

Several saplings provide powerful utility effects. The Tree of Time Sapling grows a magical tree that greatly accelerates the growth speed of nearby crops and machines. The Tree of Transformation Sapling slowly converts the surrounding biome into the Enchanted Forest over time. The Miner’s Tree Sapling uses its underground roots to extract valuable ores from below and bring them to the surface. The Sorting Tree Sapling automatically pulls items from nearby chests and organizes them into other containers. Finally, the Rainbow Oak Sapling grows a visually striking oak tree with multicolored leaves that continuously cycle through the color spectrum.

The Twilight Forest introduces a wide range of unique materials and resources that support advanced crafting and progression. Armor Shards are small fragments dropped by Helmet Crabs and are intended for crafting Knightmetal equipment. Borer Essence is a rare drop from Tower Borers and is mainly used in specialized crafting recipes. Carminite is a volatile, redstone-like substance found in the Dark Tower and is used for advanced machinery and gadgets.

Fiery Blood is a rare fluid dropped by the Hydra and is used to infuse iron into Fiery Ingots. Fiery Ingots are used to craft powerful gear that sets enemies on fire and automatically smelts mined ores. Ironwood Ingots are created by combining iron with Liveroot and gold, producing magical equipment with built-in enchantments. The raw materials for Ironwood consist of Liveroot and gold before processing.

Knightmetal is a heavy-duty metal forged from Armor Shards and is used for durable weapons and armor. Naga Scales are dropped by the Naga and are used to craft lightweight but protective armor pieces. Steeleaf is an organic magical material found in dungeon chests and is used to craft gear that often comes pre-enchanted. Liveroot is a rare plant found in hollow hills and serves as a core ingredient for Ironwood. Torchberries are glowing plants found in caves and are used to craft torches and Magic Map Focuses, while Raven’s Feathers are dropped by Forest Ravens and are required for magic map crafting. Transformation Powder is a magical substance used to convert Twilight Forest mobs into their Overworld equivalents and vice versa.

The mod also features several themed equipment sets. The Fiery Set provides fire resistance, ignites enemies, and offers high durability. The Ironwood Set is a mid-tier option that comes with useful enchantments such as Aqua Affinity and Efficiency. The Steeleaf Set is highly enchantable and commonly includes enchantments like Fortune, Looting, or Protection. Finally, the Naga Scale Tunic and Leggings provide lightweight armor with strong protection and frequent defensive enchantments.

The Twilight Forest includes a wide selection of charms, maps, utility items, and consumables that support exploration, survival, and progression. Charms of Keeping are available in three tiers and allow players to retain part or all of their inventory upon death depending on the tier. Charms of Life automatically activate when the player’s health reaches zero, consuming themselves to heal the player and apply beneficial effects.

Mapping tools are essential for navigating the dimension. A Blank Magic Map is used to create a Magic Map, which reveals Twilight Forest terrain and displays icons for boss structures. Crafting a Magic Map requires a Magic Map Focus made from Torchberries and Raven Feathers. For underground exploration, Blank Maze Maps can be crafted into Maze Maps that reveal the layout of Minotaur Labyrinths. Maze Map Focuses are rare components used for maze mapping. More advanced options include Blank Maze/Ore Maps, which can become Maze/Ore Maps that display both labyrinth paths and nearby ore veins.

Utility tools include the Ore Magnet, which pulls ore blocks toward the player from underground, and the Ore Meter, a work-in-progress device intended to help locate specific ores. The Tower Key is a progression item required to unlock sealed doors inside the Ur-ghast’s Dark Tower.

The mod also adds several unique food items. Experiment 115 is a cake-like food found in the Dark Tower with high saturation. Maze Wafers are a common bread-style food found in labyrinths. Meef, dropped by Minoshrooms, can be eaten raw or cooked into Meef Steak, or crafted into Meef Stroganoff, which is required to progress through the swamp biome. Twilight Deer drop Venison, and the Hydra Chop is a powerful late-game food providing massive saturation and health regeneration.

This mod adds a collection of automation- and redstone-focused features designed to expand vanilla-style mechanics without overcomplicating gameplay. Animals Eat Floor Food allows vanilla animals to automatically consume their breeding food directly from the ground whenever they are able to be fed manually, as long as the food item is nearby. Chain Linkage enables players to link boats or minecarts together by right-clicking them in sequence, allowing the creation of trains that remain closely connected.

The Chute is a new automation block that instantly drops any inserted items directly below it, always centered. Items can be inserted via automation such as hoppers or droppers, and the Chute can be disabled using a redstone signal or by placing a block underneath it. Dispenser Records allows dispensers to interact with jukeboxes, playing records when a jukebox is placed in front, and returning records back into the dispenser if one is already playing.

Several redstone components are introduced. The Ender Watcher emits a full redstone signal when a player looks directly at it. Metal Buttons are crafted by combining wooden buttons with iron or gold ingots; gold buttons emit very short pulses, while iron buttons emit long pulses lasting several seconds. Obsidian Pressure Plates only activate when players step on them. Pistons can now push dropped items, while sticky pistons are able to pull them back.

Additional components include the Rain Detector, which outputs a full signal during rain or snow and can be inverted by right-clicking, the Redstone Inductor, which sums signals from three sides and can be locked to preserve its output, and the Redstone Randomizer, which randomly outputs a signal to the left or right when powered. Finally, the Sugar Block acts as a storage block that falls like sand and dissolves when placed next to water.

This mod expands Minecraft’s building options with a wide variety of decorative blocks that stay close to a vanilla aesthetic while greatly increasing creative freedom. Bark Blocks are log-style blocks with bark textures on all sides and can be crafted into walls. Carved Wood serves as a core decorative wood block, while Charred Nether Bricks provide a dark, slate-like tone with stair and slab variants. Duskbound Blocks introduce purple-themed blocks with full building variants and matching Duskbound Lamps.

Framed Glass offers a rustic or medieval look and includes pane variants. Hardened Clay Tiles add tiled designs for hardened and stained clay in all colors, with stairs and slabs suitable for roofs. Iron Plates, Magma Bricks, and Midori Blocks further diversify materials, with Midori acting as a green counterpart to Purpur. Sandstone receives additional variants such as Polished Sandstone and Sandstone Bricks for both normal and red sandstone, expanding slab and stair options.

Nether and stone-themed additions include Polished Netherrack, Polished Stone, Sandy Bricks, Snow Bricks, and Soul Sandstone, all supporting standard building variants. Quilted Wool introduces framed wool blocks in every color, while Stained Planks add pastel-colored wooden planks with stairs and slabs. Sturdy Stone is a piston-immovable block using a furnace-like texture.

Organic and utility blocks include Sugar Cane Blocks, Thatch, and Turf, all reversible and usable for stairs and slabs. The mod also adds stairs, slabs, and walls for many vanilla materials, along with World Stone Bricks and World Stone Pavement inspired by Portuguese sidewalks, making it ideal for detailed and varied builds.

The core feature of the Waystones mod is the Waystone itself, a teleportation structure that commonly generates in villages and, on rare occasions, spawns randomly throughout the world. Waystones allow players to instantly travel between previously activated locations. Short-distance travel is free, while longer-distance teleportation consumes Experience levels. In addition to naturally generating, Waystones are fully craftable, allowing players to strategically place fast travel points wherever needed.

Waystones greatly enhance exploration and mobility by reducing long travel times, while still maintaining balance through experience costs. Once a Waystone is activated, it becomes part of the player’s teleport network and can be accessed through various items provided by the mod.

The mod also introduces several teleportation-related items. The Return Scroll allows players to teleport back to their most recently used spawn point, such as a bed or Waystone. Bound Scrolls enable players to share access to activated Waystones with others, making coordinated travel easier in multiplayer environments. Warp Scrolls allow direct teleportation to a previously activated Waystone, while the Warp Stone acts as a rechargeable alternative that can be reused instead of being consumed.

Additional specialized teleportation tools include the Sharestone, which functions like a Waystone but only connects to others of the same color, enabling segmented travel networks. Portstones act as one-way teleporters that send players to a chosen activated Waystone. Finally, Warp Plates come in linked pairs and allow teleportation between each other once connected using an Attuned Shard, supporting custom and automated travel setups.

Nature’s Compass is a utility item that helps players locate any biome in the game, including those added by mods. It is designed to simplify exploration by removing the guesswork involved in finding specific environments needed for progression, resources, or structures.

Using the Nature’s Compass is straightforward. By right-clicking the compass, players can either type the name of the biome they want to locate or scroll through a complete list of all available biomes. Each biome entry displays useful information such as its name, weather type, biome tags, and the mod it originates from, making it especially helpful in large modpacks with many custom biomes.

After selecting a biome and double-clicking it, the compass will begin searching for the nearest instance of that biome within a 10,000 block radius of the player’s current position. If a valid biome is found within this range, the compass will guide the player toward it. If no matching biome exists within the search radius, the compass will not activate, indicating that the player may need to travel further away before attempting another search.

Nature’s Compass is particularly valuable in modded environments where biome distribution can be complex or unfamiliar. By providing clear biome information and directional guidance, it saves time, reduces frustration, and encourages more focused exploration.

The Aether is one of the most iconic dimension mods in Minecraft, often described as the celestial opposite of the Nether. It introduces a floating world of sky islands filled with unique ores, mythical creatures, and dangerous dungeons. In modern modpacks, players typically encounter either the maintained version of Aether I or the expanded Aether II, both of which share core mechanics and progression systems.

Accessing the Aether requires a special portal distinct from other dimensions. Players must construct a vertical 4x5 frame made entirely of Glowstone. To activate the portal, the inner bottom block of the frame is right-clicked with a Water Bucket, instantly opening a gateway to the Aether. Unlike the Nether, falling out of the dimension does not result in immediate death. Instead, players fall through the clouds and respawn safely in the Overworld at the same X and Z coordinates, but high in the sky.

The Aether follows unique gameplay rules that differ significantly from the Overworld. Standard tools such as Iron and Diamond are highly ineffective, breaking slowly and losing durability rapidly. To progress efficiently, players must craft Aether-specific tools made from materials like Skyroot, Holystone, and Zanite. Fire-based mechanics and TNT do not function in this dimension, removing common combat and mining strategies.

Survival heavily depends on mobility. Parachutes are a critical item crafted from Cloud Parashots, allowing players to glide safely between floating islands and survive long falls, making them essential for exploration and progression.

The Aether features a distinct material and progression system that differs significantly from the Overworld. Skyroot is harvested from Skyroot Trees and functions as the basic wood equivalent. When used to craft sticks or bowls, Skyroot tools provide double drops, making it valuable early on. Holystone is the most common rock type in the Aether and serves as the stone equivalent. When mined, it occasionally drops Ambrosia Shards, which are useful for survival and progression.

Zanite is a purple ore that acts as the Aether’s iron-tier material. Zanite equipment has a unique mechanic where its strength increases as durability decreases, rewarding continued use. Gravitite is a rare pink ore that functions as the diamond-tier material of the Aether. Gravitite blocks naturally float upward unless restrained, and tools crafted from Gravitite can launch mobs into the air, offering strong combat utility.

Progression in the Aether is structured around a tiered dungeon system. Dungeon blocks cannot be mined until the dungeon boss is defeated, enforcing linear progression. The Bronze Dungeon, also known as the Labyrinth, features a maze-like structure filled with Mimics and Sentries. Its bosses are the Sentry Queen or the Slider, and its loot includes Valkyrie tools or the Phoenix Bow.

The Silver Dungeon, called the Valkyrie Temple, is guarded by the Valkyrie Queen. Players must first earn Victory Medals by defeating lesser Valkyries before the boss will engage. Completing this dungeon rewards Valkyrie Armor, which grants enhanced mobility such as flight or high jumps. The final tier is the Gold Dungeon, the Sun Spirit’s Peak, where players face the Sun Spirit in a dialogue-based encounter inside a massive golden sphere. Victory is achieved by reflecting fireballs back at the boss, rewarding players with Phoenix Armor or access to the Sun Altar.

The Aether is home to a variety of unique creatures that play important roles in exploration, mobility, and survival. One of the most iconic creatures is the Moa, a large, rideable bird commonly used for transportation across floating islands. To obtain a Moa, players must first find a Moa Egg and hatch it using Ambrosia Shards. Moas come in different colors, and each color corresponds to a different jump capacity, making some Moas more valuable for traversing large gaps or vertical terrain.

Another notable creature is the Phyg, a flying pig native to the Aether. Phygs can be ridden using a saddle and provide an alternative means of aerial movement. However, they are more difficult to control than Moas, making them less reliable for precise travel but still useful in certain situations.

Aerobunnies are small, passive creatures with a unique survival function. Players can pick them up and place them on their head, which significantly reduces fall speed. This makes Aerobunnies especially helpful in emergencies or early exploration before parachutes or advanced gear are available.

Swets are hostile, gelatinous blue creatures that inhabit the Aether. They attempt to absorb players on contact, pulling them inward and potentially pushing them off island edges. Because of the Aether’s vertical terrain and floating islands, Swets can be particularly dangerous when encountered near cliffs, requiring players to remain alert at all times.

Simple Storage Network (also known as SSNetwork or SSN) is a lightweight storage mod designed to provide an easy-to-use, expandable, and power-free storage system, making it ideal for early-game progression. The mod centers around connecting multiple inventories into a single network that can be accessed through tables or remotes. The core of every network is the Storage Network Master, which is mandatory and allows remotes to bind to the system. Storage inventories such as chests are connected using Storage Link Cables, while basic Storage Cables are used only to connect components together.

The mod includes several functional cables: Import Cables pull items from external inventories into the network, Export Cables push items out of the network, and Processing Cables enable basic automation and autocrafting when paired with a Controller. Each special cable (non-basic) can only connect to one inventory at a time and can be configured with a Crescent Hammer if multiple inventories are adjacent.

The Storage Request Table acts as the main interface, allowing players to view all stored items, retrieve them, and craft using an integrated 3x3 crafting grid. Multiple request tables can exist in the same network. Controllers are only required for advanced automation and crafting requests using Processing Cables.

Cable upgrades enhance Import and Export Cables: Speed Upgrades increase transfer rate, Stack Upgrades increase stack size per operation, Operation Upgrades control behavior based on inventory conditions, and Stock Upgrades (export-only) limit how many of an item may be exported.

Two remotes are available: the Storage Remote provides full wireless access including crafting within 64 blocks of the master, while the Simple Storage Remote allows unlimited-range access without crafting. Both remotes require being in the same dimension as the network.

Setting up a Simple Storage Network (SSN) starts with a basic configuration that requires only a few components. Every network must include exactly one Storage Network Master, which acts as the central binding point for the system. At least one inventory, such as a chest, must be connected to the network using a Storage Link Cable. A Storage Request Table is used as the main interface to view, retrieve, and craft with items stored in the network. All components are linked together using Storage Cables. Once assembled, any item stored in the connected inventories can be accessed through the Storage Request Table.

Expanding an SSN is straightforward and has no hard limits. Additional inventories can be added simply by placing more chests (or other inventories) and attaching them to the network with Storage Link Cables. As long as there is physical space and enough cables, the network can grow indefinitely. For convenience, it is strongly recommended to craft a Storage Remote early, allowing access to the network from a distance.

Beyond basic storage, SSN supports limited advanced functionality. Storage Link Cables can be configured with priority values, which control where incoming items are stored. Inventories with lower priority values are checked first, allowing players to direct specific items into designated storage before filling others. Storage Link Cables can also be set to Output Only mode, meaning items inside the connected inventory are accessible, but new items will never be inserted into it by the network.

Import and Export Cables enable interaction with external systems. Import Cables pull items into the network, while Export Cables push items out. Both support blacklist and whitelist filtering, allowing precise control over which items are transferred. This enables automation such as feeding fuel into generators or pulling generated items directly into storage.

Basic automation is possible by combining Processing Cables with automated crafting blocks from other mods. This allows simple automated processing chains and crafting tasks to be integrated into the SSN.

Serene Seasons is a Minecraft mod that introduces a dynamic seasonal system to the game world, adding visual, environmental, and gameplay changes that evolve throughout the in-game year. The mod divides the year into four distinct seasons—spring, summer, autumn, and winter—each influencing the environment in noticeable ways. Grass, leaves, and foliage gradually change color as seasons progress, creating a more immersive and natural-looking world that reflects the passage of time.

Temperature mechanics are also affected by the seasonal cycle. During winter, temperatures drop, allowing snow to fall in biomes that would not normally experience snowfall. This change can alter terrain appearance and environmental behavior, making cold seasons feel meaningfully different from warmer ones.

Seasons in Serene Seasons directly impact gameplay systems such as crop growth and agriculture. Certain crops may grow faster or slower depending on the current season, encouraging players to plan farming activities around the seasonal calendar. Weather patterns are also influenced, reinforcing the feeling of a living, changing world.

Beyond visuals and farming, the mod integrates season-based effects into multiple game mechanics, enhancing realism without overly complicating gameplay. Serene Seasons is designed to work alongside vanilla mechanics and other mods, adding depth and immersion while remaining intuitive and accessible for survival gameplay.

XP Tome is a lightweight gameplay-focused Minecraft mod created by bl4ckscor3 that adds a single utility item designed for safely storing player experience. The mod introduces the XP Tome item, a book that can hold and return experience levels on demand, making it useful for preventing XP loss on death or for managing experience more efficiently during gameplay.

The XP Tome has a fixed storage capacity of up to 30 experience levels, which corresponds to a total of 1,395 XP points. Once this limit is reached, the tome cannot store additional experience until some is withdrawn. The stored XP is bound to the item itself, allowing players to carry it in their inventory as a portable experience container.

Using the XP Tome is intentionally simple. Sneaking and right-clicking with the tome will store as much of the player’s current XP as possible, up to the maximum capacity of the book. Right-clicking without sneaking will retrieve all stored XP and return it directly to the player. There are no complex interfaces, power requirements, or configuration options involved.

Because of its simplicity and balance-friendly design, XP Tome integrates well into both vanilla-style survival gameplay and heavily modded environments. It is commonly used in modpacks to provide a convenient but limited solution for XP management without removing the risk-reward aspects of experience entirely.

Bounty Boards are a gameplay feature that provide players with optional tasks called bounties, which can be completed for rewards. Bounty Boards are indestructible blocks and cannot be crafted by players. In order for a Bounty Board to function and generate bounties, villagers must be present nearby. Each bounty normally takes 2 minutes (2,400 ticks) to generate, and this generation time is reduced as more villagers are placed near the board, up to a maximum of 15 villagers. Despite villager bonuses, there is a hard minimum generation time of 10 minutes (12,000 ticks) per bounty. Once a bounty is generated, its internal timer immediately begins counting down.

Each bounty will contain either one or two objectives that the player must complete. These objectives fall into two main categories: delivering specific items or killing specific mobs. The requirements are clearly defined on the bounty itself, allowing players to know exactly what actions are needed before attempting completion.

To complete a bounty, the player must right-click any Bounty Board while holding the bounty item. The board used for completion does not need to be the same board that originally generated the bounty. For bounties that involve killing mobs, the bounty item must remain in the player’s inventory while the required mobs are being defeated; otherwise, progress will not be counted.

Bounties are divided into four different rarity tiers. Higher-rarity bounties provide greater rewards upon completion, granting more experience points and a higher number of Worth Units. This rarity system encourages players to pursue more challenging bounties in exchange for better rewards.

BetterNether is a large-scale overhaul mod that completely redesigns the Nether into a diverse, hostile, and visually rich ecosystem. Rather than a repetitive netherrack wasteland, the Nether becomes a living dimension filled with unique environments, new materials, and progression paths that reward exploration. The mod introduces over 20 distinct biomes, each featuring custom fog density, terrain composition, plants, and ambient atmosphere. Examples include Nether Grasslands, which are dense vegetation zones featuring glowing Nether Grass; Wart Forests, which expand upon vanilla Crimson and Warped Forests with massive, twisted fungal structures; Sulfuric Vineyards, which are hazardous regions filled with sulfur clouds and acidic plant life; and poorly lit underground caves populated by bioluminescent fungi such as Lucent Moss.

Progression in BetterNether is supported by new materials that bridge the gap between Diamond and Netherite. One of the most common is Cincinnasite, often referred to as the "Iron of the Nether." It generates in large metallic veins and is primarily used for decorative blocks, mid-tier tools, and functional structures. A key crafting block, the Cincinnasite Altar, enables specialized recipes unique to the mod.

For higher-tier progression, Nether Ruby is introduced as a rare gemstone found deep within netherrack. Ruby-based tools and armor offer strong performance and typically higher enchantability compared to Diamond equipment. Additionally, BetterNether adds Nether-native plant resources such as Nether Reed and Bark, harvested from giant trees and wet biomes. These materials allow players to craft essential wood-based items like chests, doors, and signs entirely within the Nether, supporting extended Nether-only survival gameplay.

BetterNether expands Nether progression with essential machinery, new lifeforms, and mechanics that enable long-term Nether-only survival. Key functional blocks are required to thrive in the dimension. The Cincinnasite Forge acts as a high-efficiency furnace designed to run on specialized Nether fuels, making it central to mid-game crafting. Soul Glass is created by smelting Soul Sand and is primarily used for unique aesthetic builds and mirror-like decorative structures. The Blackstone Stovetop functions as a cooking station for the many new food sources introduced by the mod.

The Nether is populated with custom flora and fauna that make the dimension feel alive and dangerous. Naga are flying, serpent-like creatures that are generally neutral but become problematic when players build at high elevations. Fireflies are small ambient mobs that provide natural lighting in darker biomes, enhancing atmosphere. Hydrogen Jellyfish are floating entities that explode when exposed to fire, creating environmental hazards. Jungle Skeletal Horses are rare mounts found in heavily overgrown Nether regions, offering unique mobility options.

BetterNether is designed to support a full "Nether Start" survival experience. Since water is unavailable, players must rely on Nether Cactus or Agave, which can be processed to obtain moisture or liquid substitutes. Food sustainability is achieved through items such as Magma Cream Stew and Nether Mushrooms. Respawn Obelisks, enhanced alternatives to Respawn Anchors, provide more stable and reliable respawn points within the Nether.

For integration, BetterNether is commonly paired with BetterEnd and requires BCLib for biome blending and data handling. Shader users should be cautious, as volumetric fog and translucent plant effects can impact performance. Explorers are encouraged to seek out Nether Cities—massive procedurally generated structures built from Cincinnasite and Obsidian that contain powerful loot but are heavily guarded by dangerous mobs.
